div.ab: and the other two legs must do the same.

10. Such movement, running or walking.
One sees people doing naturally,
Whether in motion or standing still.
If this is observed well in our profession
So in children, men and women,
Our labor shall be properly crowned;
We must take care not to have the arm and leg
Move forward on the same side of the figure.
An action common in people and animals, walking or stepping forward.

11. But we need to consider an exchange;
let the right arm come forward
and the right leg hang back,
and the left leg come forward while, conversely,
the left arm goes back,
always crosswise. Whether the figures are sitting
or standing, the face must follow
the arm which moves forward.
left-middleOn employing a crosswise action, which masters from ancient and modern times have offered to us as examples.

12. Raphael of Urbino and Michaelangelo,
have shown such postures in their artistic work; the like
can also be found in antiquity,
in various figures, artfully carved;
and in the beautiful city of Florence
is such charm to be noted
in the well-sculpted work of Giovanni da Bologna.

13. In nature, one sees in standing poses
that the head is generally turned in the same direction
that the foot is pointed; and further, one notices
that the body will always settle itself and move
according to the turning of the head, which it supports.
Yet this composition is praised more fully
according to the rules of posture,
if the head is turned in a different direction from the body.
left-middleOn turning the head away from the direction of the body.

14. But/otherwise a weak poor quality will dissatisfy us;
thus must one attempt in many ways
to turn the head for the best composition,
for such can wholly destroy or embellish
the quality of the figure, in the eyes of the wise.
But no turning the head is tolerated
for sacred figures, which one tries oneâ€™s best
to make prayerful and modest.
left-middleSacred figures do not need much turning of the head.

15. Thus one shall not always be bound
by the aforementioned Pose
but, as is found to be necessary,
to vary it sometimes:
for Orpheus changed his sweet-sounding harp
and played with jarring chords
left-middleOne must strive in every way for correctness, and sometimes change things.
